stem: The nurse is evaluating clients in the stroke unit. For each finding or history element, select whether it is more commonly associated with an Ischemic Stroke or a Hemorrhagic Stroke.

rows.text: Sudden onset of 'the worst headache of my life' (thunderclap headache).
History of Atrial Fibrillation or carotid stenosis.
Clinical symptoms focal to a specific vascular territory (e.g., right-sided weakness).
Rapidly deteriorating level of consciousness and vomiting.
Primary treatment involves Thrombolytics (Alteplase) within 4.5 hours.

rationale.correct: Differentiating stroke types determines the medical path. (r1) Thunderclap headache is the hallmark of a ruptured aneurysm (Hemorrhagic). (r2) A-fib causes embolic clots (Ischemic). (r3) Both types cause focal deficits based on which part of the brain is damaged. (r4) Hemorrhaging increases ICP rapidly, causing nausea and coma. (r5) Alteplase is life-saving for clots (Ischemic) but fatal for bleeds (Hemorrhagic).
rationale.incorrect: Ischemic strokes rarely cause a severe headache or vomiting at onset; these are 'red flags' for a bleed.
clinicalPearls: The first diagnostic test for suspected stroke is a non-contrast Head CT to rule out a hemorrhage.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If a stroke patient is vomiting or has a severe headache, prioritize hemorrhagic stroke and ICP management!

mnemonic.title: B-L-E-E-D vs C-L-O-T
mnemonic.expansion: Bleed = Big headache, Low consciousness, Emesis. Clot = Carotid/Cardiac origin, Less headache, Occlusion.

reviewUnits.heading: Stroke Pathophysiology and Care
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for worsening deficits using the NIH Stroke Scale. Ischemic stroke (85%) requires revascularization. Hemorrhagic stroke (15%) requires blood pressure control and potentially surgical evacuation.
